videos.title: Charles Fox's Killing Me Softly, Why Was it a Hit? - Composer Insights
videos.description:
A journey through the hit song “Killing me softly” in order to work out what makes it such a success. We look at the design of the melody and how one phrase relates to another. We also examine the rhythmic structure and the colourful chordal scheme. Unpredictable features are drawn out as well as the elements that give the song a sense of cohesion. Through the study we discover how the song generates and releases musical tension to match perfectly the emotional mood of the song and how the surprise ending works so well. Ideal for those wanting to unpack what makes this song work and to those wanting to compose their own songs. 

⬇️Download the files
https://drive.google.com/file/d/17GZp3PkC1S6vv7IxdGoo7pjaz1VvWXr8/view?usp=sharing

18:06 - Conclusion

videos.title: The Difference Between a German 6th and a Dominant 7th - Music Theory
videos.description:
Why a German 6th sounds exactly the same as a Dominant 7th but functions very differently. This music theory lesson shows you how to construct a Dominant 7th in the key of Db and a German 6th in the key of C, drawing attention to the enharmonic differences. It explains the rules of engagement for resolving the two chords, showing how the Dominant 7th resolves in Db and how the German 6th resolves in C and then demonstrates how the two chords can interchange. A useful video for analysts, composers and performers alike.

videos.title: The Best Chords to Follow Chord III (in Major Keys) - Music Composition
videos.description:
Are you struggling to get started in writing a chord progression? If you want to use chord III what are the best options for chords to follow? This music composition lesson gives you plenty of options for chords that progress well from that starting point. This video shows you how the chord progressions work in major keys, and explores how root position chords might integrate well with occasional inversion chords. The more common progressions are included alongside some less often used progressions, which are nevertheless effective. Some progressions work well at the start of a phrase, others at the end of the phrase, while others would work best mid-phrase. If you’re a composer looking for ideal chord progressions this video is for you.

videos.title: Holst's use of Impressionist Colour - Composer Insights
videos.description:
An insight into the orchestration and harmonic language contained within Holst’s “Venus - the bringer of peace” from his Suite ‘The Planets’. Holst makes an original and colourful combination of a Horn solo with 4 Flutes and 3 Oboes, repeated with Flutes and Clarinets, all using a mostly non-functional chord language that has much in common with the French Impressionist style of Debussy and Ravel. While there is an underlying sense of Eb major other chords are used, often at phrase endings, that contradict the base key. This composer insights lesson offers a taste of the Holst style and insight into this remarkably evocative work.

videos.title: Why Every Musician Should Be a Singer Too - Music Performance
videos.description:
So why must every musician sing? Because every musician deserves to reach their full musical potential. This music performance lesson considers the broad benefits of singing for our mental, physical, and emotional health then goes on to explain how singing is every musician’s first instrument in the sense that singing was the earliest musical experience most of us enjoyed. The physical aspects are clarified relating to the connection between the voice and the ears and the benefits for improving pitching and relative pitch are explored. Barriers to singing are identified, including being tone deaf, or inexperienced in singing, or breaking voices for teenage boys, or reluctance to sing, or reticent tone. The benefits to expression in instrumental playing are also considered by using the voice to feel the shape of a phrase, learning how to breathe at phrase endings and much more.

videos.title: How Did George Shearing Compose? - Composer Insights
videos.description:
Journey through the opening of George Shearing’s “Lullaby of Birdland”. What makes his compositional approach so successful? We look at the design of the melody and how one phrase relates to another. We also examine the rhythmic structure and Shearing’s colourful use of extended chords. Unpredictable features are drawn out as well as the elements that give the song a sense of cohesion. Through the study we discover how Shearing generates and releases musical tension to match perfectly the emotional mood of the song. Ideal for those wanting to unpack what makes this song work and to those wanting to compose their own songs.

videos.title: Mozart the Master of Simplicity - Composer Insights
videos.description:
Does it get any better than Mozart? This composer insights lesson explores the first movement of Mozart’s K545 Sonata in C. The simple phrase structure and melodic design are unpacked in the context of the overall Sonata Form. Triadic ideas are contrasted with scalic figures and the transparent textures feature melody and accompaniment, featuring Alberti Bass and chordal interjections. One unusual feature of Sonata Form is examined and the sophistication of the piece is placed in the context of the simplicity of Mozart’s approach.

videos.title: Using a Common Note in Harmony - Music Composition
videos.description:
How to convert a less than satisfactory passage of harmony into a passage that works much better. In particular, there is a focus on how to use common notes (common tones) to maintain stability in the part writing when moving from one chord to the next. The video illustrates how to use the nearest available note when a common note is not available. By following this guidance your part writing will quickly improve and you will discover how effective is this approach in avoiding breaking the advisory ‘rules’ of harmony.

videos.title: The Best Chords to Follow Chord V (in Major Keys) - Music Composition
videos.description:
Are you struggling to get started in writing a chord progression? If you want to use chord V what are the best options for chords to follow? This music composition lesson gives you plenty of options for chords that progress well from that starting point. This video shows you how the chord progressions work in major keys, and explores how root position chords might integrate well with occasional inversion chords. The more common progressions are included alongside some less often used progressions, which are nevertheless effective. Some progressions work well at the start of a phrase, others at the end of the phrase, while others would work best mid-phrase. If you’re a composer looking for ideal chord progressions this video is for you.

videos.title: Rhapsodic Brahms - Composer Insights
videos.description:
An analysis of Op.79 no.2 G minor Rhapsody by Brahms. It takes Brahms a considerable number of bars to establish the home key and meanwhile he travels through a range of other keys. The melodic line is explored, including the growth of the line from the opening four note figure, alongside the bold bass line in octaves featuring wide leaps, while the middle of the texture features agitated triplets. The threads of the texture combine with a turbulent harmonic language to create the rhapsodic mood. All reveals the distinctive style of Brahms.

videos.title: What Makes Moonlight Sonata so Popular? - Inside the Mind of Beethoven
videos.description:
Beethoven’s Moonlight Sonata is one of his most famous pieces of music. Most people have heard it and many want to play it. What makes this such a popular work? Step inside the mind of Beethoven as we explore the features that make the opening movement so memorable, including the hypnotic impact of the triplet accompaniment figure, the distinctive nature of the melodic line with its repeated notes and dotted rhythms, as well as the twists and turns that keep the listener engaged in the harmony. All of this sits in the context of the unexpected Adagio opening movement but above all, Beethoven makes an emotional impact that is immediately engaging and continually draws us back to this iconic movement.

videos.title: How Motifs are Used in Baroque Style - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson unpacks Bach’s Sinfonia in B minor, drawing attention to the three motifs used to compose this piece. The three motifs are unpacked and we explore both the differences and the common ground between them. We then journey through the work and discover how these ideas are used in sequence, curtailed, presented in conversation between parts, and combined in various ways. The video gives insight into this piece, into Bach’s style, and into how to write a piece using three motifs.

videos.title: Burgmuller's Romantic Harmony - Composer Insights
videos.description:
This composer insights lesson explores the Romantic harmony of Burgmüller as written in his delightful character piece for piano “At the Christmas Tree”. It explains the overall Ternary structure of the piece then how the internal phrase structure works, before moving on to the attractive and memorable melodic features as well as the design of the texture. We then discover how the composer uses colourful harmony to support the melody and the structure while painting the rises and falls in the emotional life of the piece.

videos.title: Achieving Drama Through Rhythm and Modulation - Inside the Mind of Beethoven
videos.description:
Step inside the mind of Beethoven as we explore the opening section of Beethoven’s “Waldstein” Piano Sonata, one of the most famous of his middle period works. In particular we explore how rhythm and modulation are used to create drama. Starting with the fast repeated quavers of the opening, this video explains how this drives the energy of the movement in conjunction with the semiquaver runs and other rhythmic features. You will also be taken on Beethoven’s fascinating journey through a panoply of keys, including many unexpected twists and turns. The video offers insight into how this piece works and into how Beethoven writes and also inspires ideas for composers wanting to write with drama and energy.

videos.title: Modulation Using a Tritone - Music Theory
videos.description:
This music theory lesson demonstrates a method for delivering an extreme modulation a tritone away within a four bar phrase. Starting in C major the video shows how to move to F# major using an enharmonic equivalent of a German 6th chord in order to make a smooth transition to a key that is six sharps away from the starting key. This video will assist you in discovering brave modulation to extreme keys.

videos.title: Identifying Consecutive Fifths and Octaves - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson explains what constitutes consecutive or parallel fifths and octaves, before taking you through a piece of music showing you how to identify them. The video takes you through a systematic approach to searching for consecutive fifths and octaves and suggests ways of fixing them. Consecutive fifths and octaves tend to have a negative impact on harmony so it is good to have a way to find them then to repair them. A useful video for all undertaking composition, arranging, or harmony.

videos.title: The Best Chords to Follow Chord VI (in Major Keys) - Music Composition
videos.description:
Are you struggling to get started in writing a chord progression? If you want to use chord VI what are the best options for chords to follow? This music composition lesson gives you plenty of options for chords that progress well from that starting point. This video shows you how the chord progressions work in major keys, and explores how root position chords might integrate well with occasional inversion chords. The more common progressions are included alongside some less often used progressions, which are nevertheless effective. Some progressions work well at the start of a phrase, others at the end of the phrase, while others would work best mid-phrase. If you’re a composer looking for ideal chord progressions this video is for you.

videos.title: The Best Chords to Follow Chord VI (in Minor Keys) - Music Composition
videos.description:
Are you struggling to get started in writing a chord progression? If you want to use chord VI what are the best options for chords to follow? This music composition lesson gives you plenty of options for chords that progress well from that starting point. This video shows you how the chord progressions work in minor keys, and explores how root position chords might integrate well with occasional inversion chords. The more common progressions are included alongside some less often used progressions, which are nevertheless effective. Some progressions work well at the start of a phrase, others at the end of the phrase, while others would work best mid-phrase. If you’re a composer looking for ideal chord progressions this video is for you.

videos.title: Using Harmony to Influence Melody - Inside the Mind of Beethoven
videos.description:
Step inside the mind of Beethoven as we explore the opening section of an early Piano Sonata by Beethoven in F minor. In particular we examine how Beethoven derives his melodic design from the harmonic scheme. The video demonstrates this aspect of the Beethoven style and also assists composers in discovering how to write effective melody from a chord scheme.

videos.title: How to Change Key with One Note - Music Theory
videos.description:
This music theory lesson explains how to effect radical modulation by using just a single note. By using a single pivot note, rather than a pivot chord, it is possible to modulate to distant keys without making the music sound strange. We work through an example together in which, in the space of a small number of bars, we modulate from F major to Db major to A major. This is an incredibly useful trick for composers to learn and for analysts to discover.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1MPxJOXNDbAzz7gMFv38chAIN3l5iaadz/view?usp=sharing

videos.title: Hallmarks of Chopin's Poetic Style - Composer Insights
videos.description:
Chopin’s E minor Prelude is one of his most popular and most beautiful Preludes. What makes the impact of this piece so poetic? This composer insights lesson begins by examining the melodic line in the right hand. Through much of the piece the melody does little more than alternate two notes but is interspersed with more elaborate melodic and rhythmic movement. An examination of the harmony reveals a piece full of chromatic colour that paints the poetic twists and turns of this stunning Prelude.

videos.title: Identifying Double Major Thirds - Music Composition
videos.description:
What is doubling the major third? How do you know if it's a major third? Can you double thirds? Why is doubling a major third bad? This music composition lesson explains one of the rules of writing four-part harmony, namely the advice to avoid doubling major chords, and goes on to explain how to identify them in a piece of music. When writing four part harmony, particular attention should be paid to the use of thirds in chords. Thirds should normally be included but, while minor thirds can be doubled, the advice is to avoid the doubling of major thirds. We present a passage of four-part harmony that includes quite a number of chords which infringe the rule and show you how to identify the doubled major thirds and how to alter the layout of chords to correct the problem. Useful for all engaged in the writing of harmony. 

⬇️Download the files
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zWKzn1H02EagEMbV7enWqB2awxs4JXgg/view?usp=sharing

videos.title: How to Resolve a Diminished 7th Chord - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson explains the issues involved in resolving a Diminished 7th chord.  After explanation about constructing a Diminished 7th, about key referencing it, and about inversions of the chord, the video explores the two notes that need particular resolution and the implications of that for voice leading and for the choice of resolution chord. More radical treatments of Diminished 7th chords are then investigated including the use of enharmonic change and the employment of chains of Diminished 7ths.

videos.title: Playing Scales with Shape - Music Performance
videos.description:
In music exams credit is often given to candidates who can play their scales and arpeggios with shape. What does it mean to play scales and arpeggios with shape? This music performance video explores how to grade crescendos and diminuendos effectively, in combination with high quality tone in order to generate musical shape. videos.title: Three-Part Counterpoint - Music Composition
videos.description:
Learn how to write three-part counterpoint. This music composition lesson presents a short musical idea and demonstrates how to evolve it into an extended passage of three part counterpoint. The characteristics of the initial idea are considered from the perspectives of melodic and rhythmic design & harmonic implication. The video then demonstrates how to use the initial idea as a point of imitation throughout a passage scored for String Trio. Then the free parts are added showing how to vary the texture and to use ingredients of the main idea alongside chord tones and non chord tones. We end up with a complete passage of three part counterpoint.

videos.title: Pachelbel and His Canon - Music Appreciation
videos.description:
This famous work was hardly played between the death of Pachelbel and a revival of the piece during the 1960’s, since when it has been performed throughout the world in many contexts and new arrangements. This music appreciation lesson explores the repeated bass line (the ostinato) and repeated chord pattern that goes on throughout the piece following a pattern known as the Romanesca. The bass and chord pattern repeats 28 times while a series of 12 variations unfold above the bass in the three violin parts, which are presented in canon. Besides providing background and context to this famous Canon in D, the work is unpacked and analysed before covering a number of modern songs that embrace Pachelbel’s Romanesca pattern. 

⬇️Download the files
https://drive.google.com/file/d/18TTvfwYN5s8lqiOBR-C8MBGgi0J2UP6L/view?usp=sharing

videos.title: How to use Augmented 6th Chords in Major Keys - Music Composition
videos.description:
Learn how to construct and use augmented 6th chords in major keys. This music composition lesson explains the best ways to write approach chords to Augmented 6th chords and the best ways to resolve them. After explaining how to form Italian, French and German 6ths in a major key, the resolution chords are considered. We then go on to consider the merits or otherwise of each of the diatonic chords. Part writing issues are illustrated and potential traps are investigated in relation to parallel 5ths & 8ves, doubling of major 3rds, and false relations, which easily create difficulties in relation to progressions involving augmented 6th chords. A useful video for people wanting to work with chromatic chords.

videos.title: What is Colour in Music? - Music Appreciation
videos.description:
Colour in music can mean a number of different things. Some musicians experience Synesthesia in which particular notes, keys or chords are experienced directly in relation to particular colours. We talk about the Blues or about white noise, both terms that raise a reference to colour. The video expands on the above then goes on to explore colour in relation to chords, different textures, and to the varying colours available between one instrument or voice and another, and within the ranges of particular instruments or voices. The impact of dynamics, articulation, particular playing techniques, sound waves and instrument design all play their part in contributing to the colour and consequent emotional impact of a score. This music appreciation lesson explores the topic from the perspectives of the listener, the performer and the composer.

videos.title: Baroque Opera - Music Appreciation
videos.description:
We trace the origins of Opera from the Camerata in Italy in the late 1500’s through the early efforts of Peri and Caccini, through to Monteverdi and onwards to Caccini, to Lully in France, to Handel in England, and back to Pergolesi in Italy. We learn how Recitative was born and how Opera gradually developed from there to containing Arias, Choruses, Ballet, orchestral movements and the other features that make up Opera. We learn about the evolution of Opera Seria and Opera Buffa and how Italian Opera grew within and outside the Italian border. Join us for this fascinating story and discover how Opera was established and developed.

videos.title: What is the Baroque Orchestra? - Music Appreciation
videos.description:
The standard orchestra did not become established until the Classical period but the Baroque orchestra was well under development and this video explores how the orchestra got underway during the Baroque period in Italy, France and Germany. The Baroque orchestra could be anything from small ensembles to surprisingly large instrumental groups. Some of the instruments are familiar to us but other instruments fell out of use, while other instruments were developed in new ways beyond the Baroque. This music appreciation lesson explores the issues and sets the scene for the Symphony orchestra of the Classical period.

videos.title: Why Learn Figured Bass? - Music Theory
videos.description:
See why every musician should become familiar with figured bass. For harpsichordists and organists needing to realise figured bass in performance realising figured bass fluently with style is essential. For others it’s a useful way of understanding the mind of the Baroque composer. It’s also a helpful way of thinking about music from the bass upwards rather than the more usual approach from the top downwards. Additionally figured bass helps to think about chords in terms of intervals above the bass line. Being able to think fluently between thinking chords in roman numerals, in lead sheet presentation, and in figured bass is the most helpful way of understanding harmony from multiple perspectives. So figured bass is for all.

videos.title: Bach's Four-Part Chorale Writing - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson takes the first two phrases of a Chorale and works through a live harmonisation in the style of Bach. This video will be helpful to anyone wanting to improve their harmony and to anyone wanting to harmonise Chorales in the style of Bach. The video covers modulations and cadences, explores ways of working backwards as well as forwards, considers how to use common notes between one chord and the next, thinks out writing a bass line predominately in contrary motion with the given melody, suggests harmonic alternatives and how to evaluate the best choice in any given situation, considers how to achieve melodic integrity in each of the lines, adds colour and movement through devices such as secondary dominants and inessential notes, and explores how touches of counterpoint can be incorporated even in such a homophonic structure.

videos.title: How to Harmonize Repeated Notes - Music Composition
videos.description:
Many people struggle to know how to harmonize repeated notes. This music composition explores three strategies for dealing with such situations by harmonising the same note repeated six times. The first strategy is to consider the three diatonic chords that fit with the given note. The second strategy is to consider how to balance root position chords with inversion chords. The third strategy is to consider how to decorate the harmony with inessential notes and suspensions. A combination of these approaches ensures that repeated notes in the melodic line do not result in static harmony and a lack of progression.

videos.description:
The key movement is fast and chords do not always resolve as expected. In particular, we discover how Bach uses a number of unresolved dominant 7ths back to back, making this a radical approach for Baroque times. Discover what Bach is doing and how successfully it works. We also take a look at the choice of harmony, the part writing, dealing with harmonic and melodic minor, plus other features of the Bach Chorale style. Useful for anyone wanting to improve their ability to write harmony, to analyse harmony, or to understand the detail of Bach’s style. Join us on this exciting journey to delve inside the mind of the great J.S.Bach.

videos.title: Using Minor 5 Chords - Music Composition
videos.description:
We consider the possibilities for using chord V as either a major or a minor chord. In the harmonic minor context used by most composers since 1600 chord V is always major but in the context of the descending melodic minor scale and in the natural minor scale chord V is minor. This music composition lesson explains when you would want to use V as a major chord or as a minor chord and considers the best approach and resolution chords. By the end of the video you will have a clear understanding of when and how to use chord V as a major or a minor chord.

videos.description:
How to write a piece of music with only five notes. This music composition lesson takes a set of five notes and considers ideas for composing or improvising a piece based on those notes. We then explore how the Australian composer, Peter Sculthorpe uses this pitch set as the basis for a short piano piece. Having seen how the pitch set is used and repeated with different rhythms we examine other features of Sculthorpe’s piece such as the use of pedal and low dynamics, as well as his permutations of the five note set. videos.title: Josquin Des Prez High Renaissance Motets - Music Appreciation
videos.description:
Discover how Josquin des Prez developed compositional style during the High Renaissance period. Josquin des Prez followed composers like Du Fay and Ockeghem, and prepared the ground for Palestrina and his contemporaries. As a singer, much of his output is choral, including the secular Chanson. Most of his writing comprised sacred repertoire, such as Mass settings, and his most significant contribution came in the form of the Motet. His style is often homophonic but also frequently imitative. He was also one of the first composers to engage with word painting and with a less melismatic approach. This music appreciation lesson explores an overview of Josquin’s music and the key features of his style, particularly through the window of the Motet.

videos.title: Beethoven's Delicate Side - Inside the Mind of Beethoven
videos.description:
Beethoven is often called ‘the bridge composer’ and emphasis is often placed on what he does to usher in the Romantic period. There is another more delicate, elegant side to Beethoven’s musical personality that has roots in the Classical period. Step inside the mind of Beethoven as we explore the opening of his Op 49 G minor Sonata and unpacks the various aspects of this more delicate style. We examine the melodic design, the ingenious phrase structure and balance, the delicate textures, the using of figuration and ornamentation and the simple but beautifully crafted harmonic structure. This video will be helpful for those performing Beethoven and for those wanting to grasp the style.

videos.title: Upside Down 7th Chords - Music Composition
videos.description:
A clever little music composition technique for you to try in your next piece. This music composition lesson begins with a reminder of how to extend triads to 7th chords in the conventional manner. It then goes on to consider an alternative way of introducing 7th chords by adding a note at the bottom of the chord rather than at the top. The result produces a way of starting with one chord, then using every note of the chord as common notes in forming the 7th of another chord. It’s a great way of creating strong chord progressions and this video will be especially helpful to composers and arrangers.

videos.title: Creating a Moving Bass Line - Music Composition
videos.description:
Discover how to transform a piece of music that is using block chords into a much more engaging presentation with a moving bass line. Taking the opening of the British National Anthem this music composition lesson demonstrates how to keep the bass line moving by adding passing notes/ passing tones, auxiliary notes/ neighbour notes, by moving to other harmony notes/ chord tones. It then demonstrates how chromatic embellishment of the bass line can add colour to what otherwise might be a rather plain piece of music. This video will help musicians to understand more fully what is going on in much of the music they play and will empower composers wanting to transform something ordinary into something much more creative and engaging.

videos.title: How to Vary the Harmony for Repeated Notes - Music Theory
videos.description:
Many composers and students of harmony worry about harmonising repeated notes in a melody. Repeated notes can make for melodic stagnation and the remedy is often to create harmonic interest but how is this achieved? This music theory lesson goes through how to select the three diatonic chords that can be interchanged while a melody note is repeated, and explains how to use inversion chords in this context. He then explains how to use chromatic chords and secondary dominants to enrich the result further. In the example worked through during this video no fewer than eight repeated notes occur back to back in the melodic line yet the harmony is hugely varied.

videos.title: Who Needs the Rule of the Octave? - Music Theory
videos.description:
This music theory lesson summarises the rule of the octave and explains how it offers insight into harmonic thinking and into Baroque harmony in particular. The rule of the octave begins with the notion of harmonising an octave of the scale in the bass using first inversion chords. We learn how the pattern is modified progressively through starting and ending with the tonic chord in root position, then employing the dominant chord in root position, then by preceding each tonic and dominant chord with a 7th chord. This pattern is explored in major and minor keys. The rule of the octave explains many of the harmonic progressions that are still regarded as strong today.

videos.title: Why There's Only One Way to Resolve a Flat II Chord - Music Theory
videos.description:
Resolving Neapolitan flat II chords? It's all about chord progression. This music theory lesson explains why the choice of resolution chords are limited, essentially because the chord functions as a pre dominant. We consider matters of voice leading, the smooth progression of parts, and the avoidance of parallels & false relations. We also examine how chord I in second inversion can be used between the flat II chord and the dominant chord. This video will empower you to use Neapolitan flat II chords in context.

videos.title: Interpreting Schubert's Impromptu in A-flat Major D.935 for Piano - Piano Interpretation
videos.description:
Understanding and interpreting your piano music allows you to bring your own unique flair and personality to a piece. Here we explore the famous Ab Impromptu by Schubert, considering the key elements of interpretation. An overview is taken of the structure then focus is given to the opening A section. We explore the internal phrase structure, the rhythmic design, the melodic shape, the harmonic language, the changes in texture, and the expressive detail in order to discover what all this implies for choice of tempo, balancing of texture, shape and emphasis within the phrase, rubato, and colour of tone. The video is designed to flag up the key indicators that inform interpretation to assist pianists learning this piece but also in order to help musicians make good decisions about the interpretation of Romantic music.

videos.title: Elaborating an Upper Voice When Using an Ascending Bass Scale - Music Composition
videos.description:
An idea for elaborating an upper melodic line over an ascending scale in the bass line. Ascending scales in the bass can be awkward to harmonise satisfactorily without generating parallels. This pattern illustrates one way of handling the situation in a way that is musically interesting and which activates an engaging use of musical tension. These kind of structures are useful for composers working in any genre and are especially for building bridges or other connections between musical ideas.

videos.title: What to Do With the Rule of the Octave - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson follows on from an earlier video about the rule of the octave and you may well want to watch our other video first. In this lesson we examine the linear implications for part writing using the chord scheme presented by the rule of the octave, with one voice centred around the tonic, another centred around the third, and yet another centred around the fifth. The video covers the logic behind the choice of melodic notes then goes on to show how the parts are combined in the first, second and third positions. Ascending and descending patterns are covered, along with examples in both major and minor keys. This video offers insight into harmonic thinking that will illuminate Baroque style and the writing of harmony more broadly.

videos.title: Alternating Inversion Chords when Harmonizing a Descending Bass - Music Composition
videos.description:
We explore one idea for harmonising a descending scale in the bass line. Many people find it easier to harmonise an ascending scale than a descending scale and most people find it easier to harmonise a scale at the top of the texture than at the bottom. In this case, we examine a neat and sequential way of harmonising a descending scale in the bass by alternating root position and first inversion chords. This also neatly avoids generating any parallels. These kind of structures are useful for composers working in any genre.

In a canon by diminution one part begins then the second part follows on several beats or bars behind using the same pitch as the first part but presented in notes of half the value. videos.title: Using Suspensions to Harmonize a Descending Bass - Music Composition
videos.description:
Here's an idea for writing a sequence based on using a chain of suspensions above a descending scale in the bass line. Descending scales in the bass can be awkward to harmonise satisfactorily without generating parallels. This pattern illustrates one way of handling the situation in a way that is musically interesting and which activates an engaging use of musical tension. These kind of structures are useful for composers working in any genre and are especially for building bridges or other connections between musical ideas.

videos.title: Composing in Sonata Form - What is Sonata Form?
videos.description:
Unravel the intricacies of Sonata Form, the preferred form for the first movement of sonatas, symphonies, and concertos. This lesson provides a comprehensive journey into the intricacies of the Sonata Form as well as potential options for alternative structures. We look at key details regarding key movement, repeated subjects, section, themes and the overall development of ideas.

⬇️Download the files
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vOCYXN-IcDLCneFvupp2B1n4bHITf9tj/view?usp=sharing

0:00 - Introduction to what is Sonata Form?
0:57 - Exposition section
8:57 - Development section
14:00 - Recapitulation section
19:12 - Conclusion

🎓 Composing in Sonata Form Course
Start writing extended pieces, develop material and learn how to compose music using Sonata Form. Sonata Form serves as the catalyst for honing your composition skills and nurturing your growth as a proficient music creator. This course begins with an explanation of Sonata Form - what it is and how it evolved during the Classical Period. We then analyse Sonata Form movements written by Mozart and Beethoven to discover how Classical Period composers wrote in this structure and in order to see how Sonata Form was to develop during the Romantic Period. The course also explains the possible variants within Sonata Form that composers might choose to explore. There follow two composition projects. In the first, we write the essentials of a Sonata Form movement in the Classical Period style, considering how to compose first and second subjects, how to develop and recapitulate material, when to include an introduction, a Coda and transition material. In the second, we write a more extended Sonata Form movement in a more contemporary style, learning to deal with the challenges of working with Sonata Form in an atonal environment.

videos.title: Harmonizing an Ascending Scale with 5-6 Alterations - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson demonstrates an idea for alternating inversions and an associated melodic pattern above an ascending scale in the bass line. Ascending scales in the bass can be awkward to harmonise satisfactorily without generating parallels. This alternating 5-6 pattern illustrates one way of handling the situation in a way that is musically interesting and which activates an engaging use of musical tension. These kind of structures are useful for composers working in any genre and are especially for building bridges or other connections between musical ideas.

videos.title: How to Write a Crab Canon - Writing Canon
videos.description:
Learn the meaning of ‘crab canon’ then proceeds to compose an example so you can see how to do it. In a crab canon, one part works forwards while a second part simultaneously works the same music in reverse. This means that one part has to be designed melodically, rhythmically and harmonically to work with the other part while following the principles of crab canon. Watch this video to discover the technique of writing a crab canon. 

⬇️Download the files
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1tgA3q0NIlCMo6VFxirF5c3qKJaQXkqha/view?usp=sharing

videos.title: Changing Harmony from Major to Minor - Music Theory
videos.description:
Discover how to harmonise the same melody in either a major key or a minor key. In many cases the implied tonality is obvious when one looks at a melodic line. Sometimes it isn’t entirely clear if a melodic phrase should be harmonised in a major key or in the relative minor. This music theory lesson starts with a melodic line and demonstrates how it can be harmonised equally successfully in both G major and E minor.

videos.title: Using Chords in the Natural Minor - Music Theory
videos.description:
Many people are comfortable working in the harmonic and melodic keys when harmonising a melodic line but feel less assured doing the same in the natural minor. In this music theory lesson we explore which chords are major, which are minor, and which are diminished. We consider how the chord lineup is different from the chord lineup in the harmonic and melodic minors. We go on to observe the harmonisation of a melody in the natural minor and consider how different the music feels when we contrast harmonisations in the natural minor with harmonisations using the harmonic minor. This video will free you up to harmonise with confidence in the natural minor.

videos.title: Conjunct and Disjunct Melody Writing - Music Composition
videos.description:
What is meant by the terms conjunct and disjunct in relation to melody writing? We listen to and look at one melody written entirely using conjunct movement and consider its merits & weaknesses. We then do the same in relation to a melody written entirely using disjunct movement. Finally we consider a melody written combining conjunct and disjunct movement and evaluate the best way of doing so. This music composition lesson will enhance your ability to evaluate the construction of a melody in terms of conjunct and disjunct movement and will help you to compose successful melodies.

videos.title: Should You Avoid Using II to I Chord Progressions? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using this particular chord progression. Why is that? This music composition lesson explains how this chord progression can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive/ parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progression is best avoided at cadence points. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use the progression more successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use this progression or not.

videos.title: When Should You Use Second Inversion Chords? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Why do second inversion chords demand special treatment? Starting with an explanation of why root position and first inversion chords are stable in themselves we are introduced to 6/4 5/3 progressions and passing 6/4 chords, as the safest places to employ second inversion chords.  Specific examples are explored so you can see and hear how and why second inversions require resolution and how best to make them work.

videos.title: 4 Chord Progressions to Avoid - Music Theory
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using certain chord progressions. Why is that? This music theory lesson explains how the chord progressions under consideration can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive / parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progressions are best avoided at cadence points. We consider the smooth progression of individual voices and how certain progressions create awkward leaps and we hear examples where alternative choices of chords generate more convincing outcomes. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use each of the progressions successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use these progressions or not. 

⬇️Download the files
https://drive.google.com/file/d/16cDI7V3tKzjKVuLgLzKXlN5wKf1MKjPw/view?usp=sharing

videos.title: Harmony Using Primary Chords - Music Composition
videos.description:
In this music theory lesson we look at three melodies, each capable of being harmonised using only primary chords. The video shows how to treat the melody notes as chord tones or as non-chord tones, and how to find primary chords to fit. The chords are presented in both lead sheet style and in Roman Numerals. videos.description:
Are you a pianist wanting to play the organ? Ever wondered how an organ works? This informative lesson breaks down the complexities of the instrument, from its multiple keyboards to its intricate stop system. Learn about the differences between the Great, Swell, and Choir organs, the role of the pedalboard, and the function of stops like flutes, diapasons, and reeds. Discover the unique sounds and techniques that make the organ such a powerful and versatile instrument.

videos.title: Why Not Use a V-II Chord Progression? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using this particular chord progression. Why is that? This music composition lesson explains how this chord progression can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive / parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progression is best avoided at cadence points. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use the progression more successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use this progression or not.

videos.title: The Harmonic Series Explained - Music Theory
videos.description:
Join us and discover the harmonic series, or overtone series. This music theory lesson begins with a fundamental note and explains how to derive the overtones from that note that comprise the harmonic series. The video uses the principles of brass playing as a guide to how it all works and lists the first 16 notes of a harmonic series based on C as a fundamental note. We go on to learn how the valves and the slide work on brass instruments in order to capture every semitone / half step of the chromatic scale by combining different transpositions of the harmonic series. We also discover how these overtones enrich the sound of the fundamental note.

videos.title: The Difference Between Major and Minor Pentatonic Scales - Music Theory
videos.description:
We begin with a reminder of what is a pentatonic scale and how a pentatonic scale can be transposed. We go on to hear and look at a short melody written in C major pentatonic before comparing that with another melody written in A minor pentatonic. We see and hear how the tonic of the two melodies differs and how that enables us to define the melody as major pentatonic or minor pentatonic. This music theory lesson will be useful to those playing in major pentatonic and minor pentatonic and will also help those who are writing in major and minor pentatonic.

videos.title: Why Does it Matter How We Spell Musical Notes? - Music Theory
videos.description:
We consider the spelling of notes, or enharmonics. Why do notes have more than one name? How do we know when to call a note Gb or F# or even E double sharp? This music theory lesson explains why the spelling of notes matters and gets into the reasons why it might be right to choose one spelling of a note over another. We examine a melody and a passage of harmony where correct spellings and incorrect spellings appear.

videos.title: Is VI-I a Good Chord Progression? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using this particular chord progression. Why is that? This music composition lesson explains how this chord progression can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive / parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progression is best avoided at cadence points. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use the progression more successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use this progression or not.

videos.title: Cool Extended Chord Progressions - Music Composition
videos.description:
You may be someone who is used to using certain chords over and over again or you may be someone who is confident using diatonic chords but who is reluctant to explore more colourful harmony. This lesson explores the impact of 7th, 9th, 11th and 13th chords, covering possibilities for voicing those chords, how one extended chord might best progress to another, how you might impose a melody or a moving bass on an extended chord progression, and different things you could do with the texture. Conventional and less conventional progressions are investigated, along with chromatic alterations to extended notes within the chord. In short this series of videos will open your mind to new possibilities and encourage you to explore more. For many viewers this will be a real game changer. This video belongs to a set of 8 videos focused on using extended chords to create more colourful harmony.

videos.title: How to Write in Parallel, Contrary, Oblique and Similar Motion - Voice Leading
videos.description:
Dive into the fascinating world of voice leading, a vital skill for composers and musicians. Learn how to craft harmonious interactions between musical parts, whether they're sung, played by instruments, or performed on a keyboard. This lesson unveils the four fundamental techniques of voice leading—parallel motion, contrary motion, oblique motion, and similar motion—with clear examples and practical tips for creating beautiful, cohesive music. Ideal for anyone looking to enhance their compositional skills, this is the first in a 12-part series designed to deepen your understanding of this essential musical concept.
